src: 后现代主义学习方法给人带来绝对的自由。并没有一种学习方法是好的学习方法。 事实上，没有任何事情需要特意学习。在学习者体验到知识呈现的时候，学习的行为就发生了。 目前我们对所有以 DIY 、展示信息以及以学习为主要内容的电视节目的体验，都说明了这一点。 我们中有很多人，都发现自己观看的电视节目在告诉我们某种过程或经验，但我们却永远不会参与或应用这些知识。 我们永远不会对汽车进行大修，不会在后院建喷泉，不会去秘鲁考察古代遗迹，也不会改造邻居的房子。
mt: Postmodernist learning methods give people absolute freedom. There is no good learning method. In fact, nothing needs to be learned intentionally. Learning happens when knowledge is experienced. Our experiences with all DIY, infomercials, and learning-oriented television shows indicate this. Many of us have found ourselves watching television shows that tell us about a process or experience, but we never participate or apply this knowledge. We never fix our own cars, build fountains in our backyards, go to Peru to study ancient ruins, or remodel our neighbors' houses.
ref: The postmodern approach to learning offers the freedom from absolutes. There is no one good way to learn. In fact, there is not one good thing to learn.Learning takes place in the experience between the learner and the knowledge presented. Our current experience with all the do-it-yourself and information presenting, learning-based television shows illustrates this point. So many of us find ourselves watching a television show that informs us of a process or experience in which we will never participate or apply that knowledge. We will never overhaul a car, build a fountain in our backyard, travel to Peru to examine ancient ruins, or remodel our neighbour's house.

src: 睡眠中断是指这样的过程：在正常睡眠期间有意地醒来，并且在短时间之后（10-60分钟）睡着。 这很容易做到，使用相对安静的闹钟，让你在不被完全吵醒的情况下苏醒。 如果你发现自己会在睡觉时重置闹钟，可以将闹钟放到房间的另一边，逼迫自己下床去关闹钟。 其他基于生物节律的选择包括睡前大量饮用液体（尤其是水或茶——众所周知有利尿作用），强迫自己起来小便。
mt: Interrupted sleep is a process where you wake up intentionally during normal sleep and fall asleep again within a short time (10-60 minutes). This is easy to do by using a relatively quiet alarm clock that wakes you up without fully waking you up. If you find yourself resetting the alarm clock while sleeping, put the alarm clock on the other side of the room, forcing you to get up to turn off the alarm clock. Other choices based on biological rhythms include drinking a lot of liquid before going to bed (especially water or tea, which are known to have diuretic effects), forcing yourself to get up to urinate.
ref: Sleep interruption is the process of purposefully awakening during your normal sleep period and falling asleep a short time later (10–60 minutes). This can be easily done by using a relatively quiet alarm clock to bring you to consciousness without fully waking you. If you find yourself resetting the clock in your sleep, it can be placed on the other side of the room, forcing you to get out of bed to turn it off. Other biorhythm-based options involve drinking lots of fluid (particularly water or tea, a known diuretic) prior to sleep, forcing one to get up to urinate.

src: 有些人认为，经常做人工诱导、清晰的梦会让人精疲力竭。 造成这种现象的主要原因是清晰的梦境延长了快速眼动状态之间的时间间隔。 每晚快速眼动期 (REM) 越短，在这种状态下睡个好觉、恢复元气的频率就越少，身体可能会出问题。 这就像每隔二三十分钟就醒来看电视那样令人筋疲力竭。 其效果取决于你的大脑每晚做清醒梦的频率。
mt: Some people think that frequent lucid dreams can be exhausting. The main reason for this is that lucid dreams extend the time intervals between REM periods. The less time you spend in REM, the less often you will have a good night's sleep and recover your energy. This is like waking up every two or three hours to watch TV, which is exhausting. The effect depends on how often your brain has lucid dreams.
ref: Some people believe that experiencing many artificially induced lucid dreams often enough can be very exhausting. The main reason for this phenomenon is the result of the lucid dreams expanding the length of time between REM states. With fewer REMs per night, this state in which you experience actual sleep and your body recovers becomes infrequent enough to become a problem. This is just as exhausting as if you were to wake up every twenty or thirty minutes and watch TV. The effect is dependent on how often your brain attempts to lucidly dream per night.

src: 有些人认为，经常做人工诱导、清晰的梦会让人精疲力竭。 造成这种现象的主要原因是清晰的梦境延长了快速眼动状态之间的时间间隔。 每晚快速眼动期 (REM) 越短，在这种状态下睡个好觉、恢复元气的频率就越少，身体可能会出问题。 这就像每隔二三十分钟就醒来看电视那样令人筋疲力竭。 其效果取决于你的大脑每晚做清醒梦的频率。
mt: Some people think that frequent lucid dreams can be exhausting. The main reason for this is that lucid dreams extend the time intervals between REM periods. The less time you spend in REM, the less often you will have a good night's sleep and recover your energy. This is like waking up every two or three hours to watch TV, which is exhausting. The effect depends on how often your brain has lucid dreams.
ref: Some people believe that experiencing many artificially induced lucid dreams often enough can be very exhausting. The main reason for this phenomenon is the result of the lucid dreams expanding the length of time between REM states. With fewer REMs per night, this state in which you experience actual sleep and your body recovers becomes infrequent enough to become a problem. This is just as exhausting as if you were to wake up every twenty or thirty minutes and watch TV. The effect is dependent on how often your brain attempts to lucidly dream per night.

src: 虚拟团队需要坚持与传统团队同样的质量标准，但也有细微的差别。 虚拟团队成员经常担任所对应的线下团队的接洽点。 他们往往比传统的团队成员拥有更多的自主权，因为他们的团队可能会针对不同的时区安排开会时间，而本地管理层可能不理解这一点。 真正“隐形团队”的存在 (Larson 和 LaFasto，1989，p109），也是虚拟团队的一个独特组成部分。 “看不见的团队”是指每个成员都要向其汇报的管理团队。它为所有成员制定标准。
mt: Virtual teams need to maintain the same quality standards as traditional teams, but there are subtle differences. Virtual team members often act as liaisons for the corresponding offline team. They often have more autonomy than traditional team members because their teams may schedule meetings across different time zones, which local management may not understand. The existence of "invisible teams" (Larson and LaFasto, 1989, p109), is also a unique component of virtual teams. "Invisible teams" are management teams that each member reports to. It sets standards for all members.
ref: Virtual teams are held to the same standards of excellence as conventional teams, but there are subtle differences. Virtual team members often function as the point of contact for their immediate physical group. They often have more autonomy than conventional team members as their teams may meet according to varying time zones which may not be understood by their local management. The presence of a true “invisible team” (Larson and LaFasto, 1989, p109) is also a unique component of a virtual team. The “invisible team” is the management team to which each of the members report. The invisible team sets the standards for each member.

src: 虚拟团队需要坚持与传统团队同样的质量标准，但也有细微的差别。 虚拟团队成员经常担任所对应的线下团队的接洽点。 他们往往比传统的团队成员拥有更多的自主权，因为他们的团队可能会针对不同的时区安排开会时间，而本地管理层可能不理解这一点。 真正“隐形团队”的存在 (Larson 和 LaFasto，1989，p109），也是虚拟团队的一个独特组成部分。 “看不见的团队”是指每个成员都要向其汇报的管理团队。它为所有成员制定标准。

src: 激励内容理论的核心是寻找令人认同或产生兴趣的因素。 这些理论表明，当人们成熟到一定程度进入成年时，某些需求和/或欲望就被内化了。 这些理论研究为什么某些人想要做他们所做的事情，以及他们所处的环境中哪些事情会让他们做或不做某些事情。 两种流行的内容理论，分别是马斯洛的需求层次理论和赫茨贝格的双因素理论。
mt: The core of the content theory is to find the factors that can be identified or interested. These theories indicate that when people mature to a certain extent into adulthood, some needs and / or desires are internalized. These theories study why some people want to do what they do and what will make them do or not do some things in their environment. Two popular content theories are Maslow's hierarchy of needs and Herzberg's two-factor theory.
ref: Content theories are centered on finding what makes people tick or appeals to them. These theories suggest that people have certain needs and/or desires which have been internalized as they mature to adulthood. These theories look at what it is about certain people that make them want the things that they do and what things in their environment will make them do or not do certain things. Two popular content theories are Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs Theory and Hertzberg's Two Factor Theory.

src: 经常被滥用和嘲笑的三分法，在创造动态时不失为一种简单的指导方法，还能让图像保持有序。 它指出，对主体来说最有效的位置是将图像垂直和水平分为三部分的线的交叉点（见示例）。
mt: 3:1 Rule, often abused and mocked, is a simple guide to creating dynamic images, and it can help keep your images orderly. It points out the most effective position for your subject is the intersection of the lines that divide your image vertically and horizontally into thirds (see example).
ref: The much-abused and often-ridiculed rule of thirds is a simple guideline creating dynamism while keeping a measure of order in an image. It states that the most effective place for the main subject is at the intersection of lines dividing the image into thirds vertically and horizontally (see example).

src: 例如，世界上最常见的静态图像摄影格式是 35mm 格式，这是胶片电影时代末期占主导地位的电影尺寸。 时至今日仍有生产，但更重要的是它的长宽比应用到了数码相机图像传感器的格式上。 35 毫米格式的实际尺寸是 36 毫米宽，24 毫米高，这样格式其实有点令人困惑。 因此，这种格式的宽高比（除以 12 得到最简单的整数比）便是 3:2。 许多常见格式（例如 APS 格式系列）都与这个长宽比相同或相当接近。
mt: For example, the most common static image photography format in the world is 35mm format, which was the dominant movie size at the end of the film era. It is still produced, but more importantly, its aspect ratio was applied to the digital camera image sensor format. The actual size of the 35mm format is 36mm wide, 24mm high, so the format is actually a bit confusing. Therefore, the aspect ratio of this format (divided by 12 to get the simplest integer ratio) is 3:2. Many common formats (such as APS format series) are similar or close to this aspect ratio.
ref: For example, the most common still image photography format in the world is 35mm, which was the dominant film size at the close of the analog film era. It is still produced today, but more importantly its aspect ratio has been inherited by digital camera image sensor formats. The 35mm format is actually, somewhat confusingly, 36mm in width by 24mm in height. The aspect ratio of this format (dividing by twelve to obtain the simplest whole-number ratio) is therefore said to be 3:2. Many common formats (APS family of formats, for example) are equal to or closely approximate this aspect ratio.

src: 变焦镜头的缺点是，要想实现一定的焦距范围，所需的焦距复杂度和透镜元件的数量远远大于定焦镜头。 随着镜头制造商在镜头生产方面达到更高的标准，这已经不算什么问题了。 这使得变焦镜头可以拍出与固定焦距镜头质量相媲美的照片。 变焦镜头的另一个缺点是镜头的最大光圈（速度）通常较小。 这使得廉价的变焦镜头在没有闪光灯的情况下很难在弱光条件下使用。
mt: The main disadvantage of zoom lenses is that the focal length range requires a much higher focal complexity and a much larger number of lens elements than fixed focal length lenses. With manufacturers reaching higher standards in lens production, this is no longer a problem. This allows zoom lenses to produce images of comparable quality to fixed focal length lenses. Another disadvantage of zoom lenses is that the maximum aperture (speed) is usually smaller. This makes cheap zoom lenses difficult to use in low light conditions without a flash.
ref: The disadvantage of zoom lenses is that the focal complexity and number of lens elements required to achieve a range of focal lengths is much greater than for prime lenses. This is becoming less of an issue as lens manufacturers achieve higher standards in lens production. This has allowed zoom lenses to produce pictures of a quality comparable to that achieved by lenses with fixed focal length. Another disadvantage of zoom lenses is that the maximum aperture (the speed) of the lens is usually lower. This makes inexpensive zoom lenses hard to use in low-light conditions without a flash.

This has allowed zoom lenses to produce pictures of a quality comparable to that achieved by lenses with fixed focal length. src: 神秘主义追求与终极现实、神性、精神真理或上帝进行交流、认同或达成知觉意识。 信徒们寻求一种对神圣的现实/神性或诸神的直接体验、直觉或者顿悟。 追随者追求某种生活方式或旨在滋养这些经验的修行。 神秘主义可以与其他形式的宗教信仰和崇拜区分开来，因为它强调对独特意识状态的个人直接体验，特别是那些和平的、有洞察力的、幸福的、甚至是狂喜的意识状态。
mt: Mysticism is the pursuit of direct communion with ultimate reality, divinity, or God, or of a direct experience of spiritual truth or insight. Mystics seek a direct experience of the divine, or of the sacred, or of truth, or of God. Mysticism can be distinguished from other forms of religious belief and practice because it emphasizes direct personal experience, especially of peaceful, insightful, happy, or ecstatic states of consciousness.
ref: Mysticism is the pursuit of communion with, identity with, or conscious awareness of an ultimate reality, divinity, spiritual truth, or God. The believer seeks a direct experience, intuition, or insight into divine reality/the deity or dieties. Followers pursue certain ways of living, or practices that are intended to nurture those experiences. Mysticism can be distinguished from other forms of religious belief and worship by its emphasis on the direct personal experience of a unique state of consciousness, particularly those of a peaceful, insightful, blissful, or even ecstatic character.

src: 在十九世纪和二十世纪很长一段时间，人们都认为新西兰的第一批居民是毛利人，他们猎取一种称为恐鸟的大型鸟类。 然后该理论确立了这样一种观点：毛利人从波利尼西亚乘“大船”迁移，并从莫里奥里人手中夺取了新西兰，建立了一个农业社会。 但有新的证据表明，莫里奥里人属于大陆毛利人族群，他们从新西兰移居到查塔姆群岛，发展出了自己独特的崇尚和平的文化。 查塔姆群岛上还有另一个部落，他们是从新西兰移民过来的毛利人。 他们自称莫里奥里人。发生过一些小冲突，最后莫里奥里人被消灭了
mt: For a long time in the 19th and 20th centuries, people believed that the first inhabitants of New Zealand were the Maori, who hunted a large bird called the moa. Then the theory was established that the Maori came to New Zealand by boat from Polynesia and took the Chatham Islands from the Moriori, establishing an agricultural society. But new evidence shows that the Moriori are part of the mainland Maori tribe, who migrated to the Chatham Islands from New Zealand and developed their own unique culture of peace. Another tribe on the Chatham Islands is the Maori who migrated from New Zealand. They call themselves Moriori. There were some minor conflicts, and the Moriori were eventually wiped out.
ref: For a long time during the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, it was believed the first inhabitants of New Zealand were the Maori people, who hunted giant birds called moas. The theory then established the idea that the Maori people migrated from Polynesia in a Great Fleet and took New Zealand from the Moriori, establishing an agricultural society. However, new evidence suggests that the Moriori were a group of mainland Maori who migrated from New Zealand to the Chatham Islands, developing their own distinctive, peaceful culture. There was also another tribe on the Chatham islands these were Maori who migrated away from New Zealand. They called themselves the Moriori there were a few skirmishes and in the end, the Moriori were wiped out

src: 净土折纸，其限制规则是一次只能进行一次折叠，不允许反向折叠这样更复杂的动作，并且所有折叠的位置都必须简单明了。 它是由约翰•史密斯 (John Smith) 在 20 世纪 70 年代研发的，用于帮助缺乏经验的折纸人或动手能力差的人。
mt: Origami nets are limited by rules that allow only one fold at a time, no reverse folds, and all folds must be simple and obvious. It was developed by John Smith in the 1970s to help inexperienced origamists or those with limited dexterity.
ref: Pureland origami is origami with the restriction that only one fold may be done at a time, more complex folds like reverse folds are not allowed, and all folds have straightforward locations. It was developed by John Smith in the 1970s to help inexperienced folders or those with limited motor skills.

src: 印度河流域文明是青铜时代的文明，位于印度西北部次大陆，覆盖的区域包括了现代巴基斯坦的大部分地区，以及印度西北部和阿富汗东北部的一些地区。 印度河盆地的文明发展繁荣，该文明因此得名。 尽管一些学者推测，鉴于这一文明也存在于如今已然干涸的萨拉斯瓦蒂河流域，将该文明称为“印度河-萨拉斯瓦蒂河文明”才算恰如其分，不过一些人称其为“哈拉帕文明”——得名于20世纪20年代在该区域发掘的第一个遗址“哈拉帕”。
mt: The Indus Valley Civilization was a Bronze Age civilization that developed in the Indus River Valley, in modern-day Pakistan and northwestern India. The Indus Valley Civilization is named for the Indus River, which flows through the region. The Indus Valley Civilization is also known as the Harappan Civilization, after the first excavated site, Harappa. The Indus Valley Civilization is one of the world's oldest and most sophisticated civilizations. It is believed to have developed around 2500 BCE, and lasted until around 1900 BCE. The Indus Valley Civilization is known for its advanced urban planning, sophisticated water management systems, and advanced trade networks. The Indus Valley Civilization is also known for its unique script, which has not yet been deciphered.
ref: The Indus Valley Civilization was a Bronze Age civilisation in the northwest Indian subcontinent encompassing most of modern-day Pakistan and some regions in northwest India and northeast Afghanistan. The civilisation flourished in the basins of the Indus River wherefore it derives its name. Although some scholars speculate that since the civilisation also existed in the basins of the now dried up Sarasvati River, it should be aptly called the Indus-Sarasvati Civilization, while some call it the Harappan Civilization after Harappa, the first of its sites to be excavated in the 1920s.

src: 贪婪和自私永远与我们同在，合作的本质就是当大多数人受益时，短期的自私行为总能带来更多利益 希望大多数人都能意识到，从长远来看，与他人合作才是最佳选择。
mt: 1. Greed and selfishness are always with us, and the essence of cooperation is that when most people benefit, short-term selfish behavior can bring more benefits. I hope that most people can realize that cooperation is the best choice in the long run.
ref: Greed and selfishness will always be with us and it is the nature of cooperation that when the majority benefit there will always be more to gain in the short term by acting selfishly Hopefully, most people will realise that their long term best option is to work together with others.

mt: 1. Greed and selfishness are always with us, and the essence of cooperation is that when most people benefit, short-term selfish behavior can bring more benefits. I hope that most people can realize that cooperation is the best choice in the long run.
ref: Greed and selfishness will always be with us and it is the nature of cooperation that when the majority benefit there will always be more to gain in the short term by acting selfishly Hopefully, most people will realise that their long term best option is to work together with others.

src: 美帝国主义在征服菲律宾时的战争开支是由菲律宾人民自己支付的。 他们被迫向美国殖民政权纳税，用于支付大部分开支，以及通过华尔街银行以菲律宾政府名义发行的债券的利息。 当然，长期剥削菲律宾人民所获得的高额利润成为美帝国主义的基本收益。
mt: The cost of the war of conquest of the Philippines by the American imperialism was paid by the Filipino people themselves. They were forced to pay taxes to the colonial government of the United States, to pay for most of the costs, as well as the interest on the bonds issued by Wall Street banks in the name of the Philippine government. Of course, the high profits obtained by long-term exploitation of the Filipino people became the basic income of the American imperialism.
ref: The war expenditures of U.S. imperialism in the conquest of the Philippines were paid for by the Filipino people themselves. They were compelled to pay taxes to the U.S. colonial regime to defray a major part of the expenditures and the interest on bonds floated in the name of the Philippine government through the Wall Street banking houses. Of course, the superprofits derived from the protracted exploitation of the Filipino people would constitute the basic gains of U.S. imperialism.

src: 要了解圣殿骑士，就必须了解促使圣殿骑士团成立的背景。 事件发生的时代通常被称为欧洲史的中世纪盛时，即的 11、12 和 13世纪时期（公元 1000-1300 年）。 中世纪盛期之前是中世纪早期，之后是中世纪晚期，约定俗成认为中世纪晚期大约在 1500 年前后结束。
mt: To understand the Knights Templar, one must understand the background that led to the formation of the Knights Templar. The era in which the events took place is usually referred to as the High Middle Ages, the 11th, 12th and 13th centuries (1000-1300 AD). The High Middle Ages preceded the Early Middle Ages and followed the Late Middle Ages, which is generally considered to have ended around 1500 AD.
ref: To understand the Templars one must understand the context that prompted the creation of the order. The age where the events took place is commonly referred as the High Middle Ages the period of European history in the 11th, 12th, and 13th centuries (AD 1000–1300). The High Middle Ages were preceded by the Early Middle Ages and followed by the Late Middle Ages, which by convention ends around 1500.

src: 罗马帝国的军国主义性质促进了医学的进步和发展。 奥古斯都皇帝开始招募医生，甚至组建了第一支罗马医疗队，用于战后医疗。 外科医生对各种镇静剂都有了解，包括从罂粟种子中提取的吗啡和从莨菪种子中提取的东莨菪碱。 除了用止血带和动脉钳来阻止血液流动外，他们已能熟练通过截肢来挽救坏疽患者。 在几个世纪里，罗马帝国在医学领域取得了巨大成果，构成了我们今天所知晓的大部分知识。
mt: The militaristic nature of the Roman Empire promoted the advancement and development of medicine. Emperor Augustus began recruiting physicians, even forming the first Roman medical corps for post-battle medical care. Surgeons were familiar with various sedatives, including morphine extracted from poppy seeds and scopolamine extracted from henbane seeds. In addition to using tourniquets and artery clamps to stop the flow of blood, they were able to skillfully save gangrene patients through amputation. Over several centuries, the Roman Empire made great strides in the field of medicine, which forms much of what we know today.
ref: The militaristic nature of the Roman empire aided in the development of medical advances. Doctors began to be recruited by Emperor Augustus and even formed the first Roman Medical Corps for use in the aftermath of battles. Surgeons had knowledge of various sedatives including morphine from extracts of poppy seeds and scopolamine from herbane seeds. They became proficient at amputation to save patients from gangrene as well as tourniquets and arterial clamps to stem blood flow. Over multiple centuries, the Roman empire led to great gains in the field of medicine and formed much of the knowledge we know today.

src: 视觉或看的能力依赖于视觉系统的感觉器官，即眼睛。 眼睛的构造有许多种，其复杂程度取决于生物体的需要。 不同的构造有不同的功能，对不同的波长敏感，且敏锐度不同。它们也需要不同的处理方式来理解输入，并需要不同数量的输入才能达到最佳效果。
mt: The ability to see depends on the visual system's sensory organ, the eye. The construction of the eye is varied, and its complexity depends on the needs of the organism. Different constructions have different functions, are sensitive to different wavelengths, and have different sensitivities. They also need different processing to understand the input, and need different amounts of input to achieve the best effect.
ref: Vision, or the ability to see depends on visual system sensory organs or eyes. There are many different constructions of eyes, ranging in complexity depending on the requirements of the organism. The different constructions have different capabilities, are sensitive to different wave-lengths and have differing degrees of acuity, also they require different processing to make sense of the input and different numbers to work optimally.

src: 锡克教是来自印度次大陆的一种宗教。它在 15 世纪起源于旁遮普地区，来自印度教传统的内部宗派分裂。 锡克教徒认为，他们信仰的是与印度教不同的一种宗教，尽管他们承认锡克教源自印度教，也包含印度教的传统。 锡克教徒把自己的宗教称为 Gurmat，在旁遮普语中是“古鲁（导师）之路”的意思。古鲁是所有印度宗教的基本组成部分，但在锡克教中地位特别高，成为了锡克教信仰的核心。 该宗教于 15 世纪由古鲁·纳纳克 (1469-1539) 创立。随后又有九位古鲁。
mt: Sikhism is a religion that originated in the 15th century in the Punjab region of the Indian subcontinent, based on the teachings of Guru Nanak, and later influenced by the teachings of nine other gurus. Sikhism is the fifth-largest organized religion in the world, with approximately 30 million adherents. It is the majority religion in the Indian states of Punjab and Haryana, as well as in the Indian union territory of Chandigarh. In the United Kingdom, the United States, and Canada, Sikhism is the dominant religion practiced among the Indian diaspora. In India, Sikhism is the 11th largest religion, accounting for 0.58% of India's population.
ref: "Sikhism is a religion from the Indian sub-continent. It originated in the Punjab region during the 15th century from a sectarian split within the Hindu tradition. Sikhs consider their faith to be a separate religion from Hinduism though they acknowledge its Hindu roots and traditions. Sikhs call their religion Gurmat, which is Punjabi for ""way of the guru"". The guru is a fundamental aspect of all Indian religions but in Sikhism has taken on an importance that forms the core of Sikh beliefs. The religion was founded in the 15th century by Guru Nanak (1469–1539). There followed in succession a further nine gurus."

src: “注意力缺失症“是一种神经系统综合症，三种典型的限定症状包括冲动、注意力分散、多动或精力过剩。 这不是学习能力缺失，而是学习障碍；这“影响着全美儿童的 3% 到 5%，人数可能多达 200 万”。 患有多动症的孩子很难专心做事，例如做作业，但他们能够集中精力做自己喜欢的事情，比如玩游戏，看喜欢的卡通片，或者写一些不加标点符号的句子。 这些孩子往往会陷入很多麻烦。因为正常的方法无法刺激他们的大脑，为了刺激大脑，他们“做出危险行为、打架、挑战权威”。 注意力缺陷障碍（ADD）会影响患病孩童与其同龄人的关系，因为其他儿童无法理解患者做出行为、进行拼写的原因所在，也不理解为什么他们的成熟程度与众不同。
mt: "Attention Deficit Disorder" is a neurological disorder that includes three typical limitations: impulsivity, distractibility, and hyperactivity. This is not a lack of learning ability, but a learning disability; this "affects 3% to 5% of American children, possibly up to 2 million." Children with ADHD have difficulty focusing on tasks, such as homework, but can focus on things they like, such as playing games, watching cartoons, or writing sentences without punctuation. These children often get into trouble. Because normal methods cannot stimulate their brains, to stimulate their brains, they "engage in dangerous behavior, fight, challenge authority." Attention Deficit Disorder (ADD) affects the relationship between the affected child and his peers because other children cannot understand the reasons for the patient's behavior, spelling, and why their maturity is different from others.
ref: "Attention Deficit Disorder ""is a neurological syndrome whose classic defining triad of symptoms including impulsivity, distractibility, and hyperactivity or excess energy"". It is not a learning disability, it is a learning disorder; it ""affects 3 to 5 percent of all children, perhaps as many as 2 million American children"". Children with ADD have a hard time focusing on things like school work, but they can concentrate on things they enjoy doing like playing games or watching their favorite cartoons or writing sentences without punctuation. These children tend to get into a lot of trouble, because they ""engage in risky behaviors, get into fights, and challenge authority"" in order to stimulate their brain, since their brain can not be stimulated by normal methods. ADD affects relationships with other peers because other children can not understand why they act the way that they do or why they spell they way they do or that their maturity level is different."

src: 虽然项目学习法应该使学习变得更容易、更有趣，但支架式学习法却更进一步。 支架式教学不是一种学习方法，而是一种辅助刚学习使用新电脑程序或启动新项目的人的手段。 支架式教学可以线上或线下进行，换句话说，老师是支架式教学的一种形式，就像 Microsoft Office 里的回形针小助手一样。 虚拟支持内化在软件中，用来质疑、提示和解释那些可能对学生来说难以独自处理的程序。
mt: While project-based learning should make learning easier and more fun, scaffolding takes it a step further. Scaffolding is not a learning method, but rather a way to help people who are just learning to use new computer programs or starting new projects. Scaffolding can be done online or offline, meaning that teachers are one form of scaffolding, just like the little paper clip helper in Microsoft Office. Virtual support is internalized in software, used to question, prompt, and explain those programs that may be difficult for students to handle on their own.
ref: While project based learning should make learning easier and more interesting, scaffolding goes a step beyond. Scaffolding is not a method of learning but rather an aid that provides support to individuals whom are undergoing a new learning experience such as using a new computer program or beginning a new project. Scaffolds can be both virtual and real, in other words, a teacher is a form of scaffold but so is the little paperclip man in Microsoft Office. Virtual Scaffolds are internalized in the software and are meant to question, prompt, and explain procedures that may have been to challenging for the student to handle alone.

src: MySpace 是美国第三大最受欢迎的网站，目前有 5,400 万个注册帐号。 这些网站得到了很多关注，尤其是在教育领域。 这些网站也有好处，比如可以轻松创建一个包含博客、视频、照片等内容的班级页面。 只需提供一个网址，就能轻松访问该页面。这对不会用键盘或拼写有困难的学生来说，更加容易记住，输入也更简单。 它可以进行个性化设置以便阅读，也可根据需求使用或多或少的颜色。
mt: MySpace is the third most popular website in the United States, with 54 million registered accounts. These websites have received a lot of attention, especially in the educational field. These websites also have advantages, such as being able to easily create a class page containing a blog, videos, and photos. Just provide a URL to easily access the page. This is easier for students who are not good at typing or spelling, and it is also easier to remember and input. It can be customized for reading, and can be used with or without color as needed.
ref: MySpace is the third most popular website used in the United States and has 54 million profiles currently. These websites have gotten a lot of attention, especially in the education setting. There are positive aspects to these websites, which include, being able to easily setup a class page which can include blogs, videos, photos, and other features. This page can easily be accessed by providing just one web address, which makes it easy to remember and easy to type in for students who may have trouble using the keyboard or with spelling. It can be customized to make it easy to read and also with as much or little color as desired.

src: 然而，在 1956 年 6 月，当波兰工人抗议食品短缺和减薪的骚乱演变成对共产主义制度本身的抗议时，赫鲁晓夫的承诺面临着考验。 尽管在最后，赫鲁晓夫派出坦克恢复了秩序，但他还是对一些经济要求做出了让步，并同意任命受民众欢迎的瓦迪斯瓦夫·哥穆尔卡 (Wladyslaw Gomulka) 为新总理。
mt: However, in June 1956, when Polish workers protesting food shortages and wage cuts turned their protests against the communist system itself, Gomulka's promises were put to the test. Although in the end, Gomulka sent in tanks to restore order, he did make some economic concessions and agreed to appoint the popular Wladyslaw Gomulka as the new prime minister.
ref: However, in June 1956, Krushchev's promises were put to the test when riots in Poland, where workers were protesting against food shortages and wage cuts, turned into a general protest against Communism. Although in the end, Krushchev sent in tanks to restore order, he did give way to some economic demands and agreed to appoint the popular Wladyslaw Gomulka as the new prime minister.

src: 然而，在 1956 年 6 月，当波兰工人抗议食品短缺和减薪的骚乱演变成对共产主义制度本身的抗议时，赫鲁晓夫的承诺面临着考验。 尽管在最后，赫鲁晓夫派出坦克恢复了秩序，但他还是对一些经济要求做出了让步，并同意任命受民众欢迎的瓦迪斯瓦夫·哥穆尔卡 (Wladyslaw Gomulka) 为新总理。
mt: However, in June 1956, when Polish workers protesting food shortages and wage cuts turned their protests against the communist system itself, Gomulka's promises were put to the test. Although in the end, Gomulka sent in tanks to restore order, he did make some economic concessions and agreed to appoint the popular Wladyslaw Gomulka as the new prime minister.
ref: However, in June 1956, Krushchev's promises were put to the test when riots in Poland, where workers were protesting against food shortages and wage cuts, turned into a general protest against Communism. Although in the end, Krushchev sent in tanks to restore order, he did give way to some economic demands and agreed to appoint the popular Wladyslaw Gomulka as the new prime minister.

src: 德国是二战中各国的共同敌人，这促进了苏联和美国之间的合作。随着战争的结束，制度、程序和文化上的冲突又使得两国分道扬镳。 战争结束两年后，曾经的盟友如今成了敌人，冷战随即开始。 这场战争持续了 40 年，代理军队在从非洲到亚洲的很多战场上真刀真枪地战斗，包括在阿富汗和古巴。
mt: Germany was the common enemy of all the countries in World War II, which promoted cooperation between the Soviet Union and the United States. After the war, the institutional, procedural and cultural conflicts between the two countries led to their separation. Two years after the end of the war, former allies became enemies, and the Cold War began. This war lasted for 40 years, and proxy armies fought with real swords and guns on many battlefields from Africa to Asia, including Afghanistan and Cuba.
ref: Germany was a common enemy in World War 2, leading to cooperation between the USSR and USA. With the end of the war the clashes of system, process and culture led to the countries falling out. With two years of the end of the war, the former allies were now enemies and the Cold War began. It was to last for the next 40 years and would be fought for real, by proxy armies, on battlefields from Africa to Asia, in Afghanistan, Cuba and many other places.

src: 神经系统通过向全身发送神经脉冲来保持血液流动顺畅，从而维持体内平衡。 这些神经脉冲可以非常迅速地传送到全身，让身体免受任何潜在威胁的伤害。
mt: The nervous system maintains a balance of blood flow throughout the body by sending nerve impulses to the entire body, which can be very quickly transmitted to the entire body, protecting the body from any potential threats.
ref: The Nervous System maintains homeostasis by sending nerve impulses through out the body to keep the flow of blood going as well as undisturbed. These nerve impulses can be sent so quickly throughout the body which helps keep the body safe from any potential threat.

src: 吉萨大金字塔是七大奇迹中唯一至今仍屹立不倒的建筑。 大金字塔是埃及人在公元前三世纪的杰作，它是众多向已故法老表示敬意的大型金字塔的其中之一。 埃及死亡之谷的吉萨（Giza）高原（即“吉萨金字塔群”）包括多个金字塔（其中大金字塔是最大的）、几个小坟墓，几个寺庙和大狮身人面像。 大金字塔是为纪念胡夫法老而建造的，并为纪念胡夫的妻子和家庭成员建造了多座较小的金字塔、坟墓和庙宇。
mt: The Great Pyramid of Giza is the only one of the Seven Wonders of the World that still stands. The Great Pyramid was built by the Egyptians in the third century BC and is one of many large pyramids built to honor the dead pharaohs. The Giza plateau in Egypt's Valley of the Kings (the "Giza Pyramids") includes several pyramids (the largest is the Great Pyramid), several smaller tombs, several temples, and the Great Sphinx. The Great Pyramid was built to honor the pharaoh Khufu and several smaller pyramids, tombs, and temples were built to honor Khufu's wife and family members.
ref: "The Great Pyramid at Giza is the only one of the seven wonders that is still standing today. Built by the Egyptians in the third century BCE, the Great Pyramid is one of many large pyramid structures built to honor dead Pharaoh. The Giza Plateau, or ""Giza Necropolis"" in the Egyptian Valley of the Dead contains several pyramids (of which the great pyramid is the largest), several small tombs, several temples, and the great Sphinx. The great pyramid was created to honor the Pharaoh Khufu, and many of the smaller pyramids, tombs, and temples were built to honor Khufu's wives and family members."

src: 公元前 356 年 7 月 21 日，赫洛斯塔图斯 (Herostratus) 的纵火行为导致位于以弗所 (Ephesus) 的阿尔忒弥斯神庙毁于一旦。 据故事情节所写，此人愿不惜一切代价出人头地。愤慨的以弗所人宣布黑若斯达特斯（Herostratus）之名罄竹难书。 希腊历史学家斯特拉博 (Strabo) 后来提到了这个名字，也就是我们今天所熟知的名字。圣殿在亚历山大大帝出生的当晚被毁。 亚历山大大帝原本提议重建这座神庙，但其提案遭到拒绝。随后，在亚历山大死后，该神庙于公元前 323 年得以重建。
mt: 21 July 356 BC, the arson of Herostratus (Herostratus) led to the destruction of the Artemis temple in Ephesus. According to the plot, the man was willing to make a name for himself at all costs. The Ephesians were angry and declared the name of Herostratus to be written in the book. The Greek historian Strabo later mentioned this name, which is the name we are familiar with today. The temple was destroyed on the night of the birth of Alexander the Great. Alexander the Great originally proposed to rebuild this temple, but his proposal was rejected. Later, after the death of Alexander, the temple was rebuilt in 323 BC.
ref: The temple of Artemis at Ephesus was destroyed on July 21, 356 BCE in an act of arson committed by Herostratus. According to the story, his motivation was fame at any cost. The Ephesians, outraged, announced that Herostratus' name never be recorded. The Greek historian Strabo later noted the name, which is how we know today. The temple was destroyed on the same night that Alexander the Great was born. Alexander, as king, offered to pay to rebuild the temple, but his offer was denied. Later, after Alexander died, the temple was rebuilt in 323 BCE.

src: 已知的第一种交通方式是步行。200 万年前，随着直立人（Homo Erectus，意思是直立的人）的出现，人类开始直立行走。 他们的祖先南方古猿没有直立行走的习惯。 人们在 420 万至 390 万年前的南方古猿化石中发现了双足特化的现象，尽管乍得沙赫人（Sahelanthropus）可能早在 700 万年前就已经用双腿行走了。
mt: The first known mode of transportation was walking. 200 million years ago, with the appearance of Homo Erectus, humans began to walk upright. Their ancestors, the South African Ape, did not have the habit of walking upright. People have found the phenomenon of bipedalization in the fossils of the South African Ape dating back to 420 to 390 million years ago, although Sahelanthropus may have been walking on two legs as early as 700 million years ago.
ref: The first known transportation was walking, humans began walking upright two million years ago with the emergence of Homo Erectus (meaning upright man). Their predecessors, the Australopithecus did not walk upright as habitually. Bipedal specializations are found in Australopithecus fossils from 4.2-3.9 million years ago, although Sahelanthropus may have walked on two legs as early as seven million years ago.

src: 迄今为止，船运是跨洋运输大量人员和货物的最有效方式。 从传统意义上讲，海军的任务是确保国家保持运输人员和货物的能力，同时，干扰敌人运输其人员和货物的能力。 一个最值得注意的现代的例子就是二战期间的北大西洋战役。美国人尝试横跨大西洋运送人员和物资来帮助英国。 与此同时，以 U 型潜艇为主力的德国海军试图拦截这场运输。 假如同盟国当时失败了，德国原本很可能像征服欧洲其他国家一样征服英国。
mt: Shipping is the most effective way to transport large numbers of people and goods across oceans. From a traditional perspective, the navy's task is to ensure that a country maintains the ability to transport its people and goods while disrupting the enemy's ability to transport its people and goods. One of the most notable modern examples is the Battle of the Atlantic during World War II. The Americans were trying to transport people and supplies across the Atlantic to help the British. At the same time, the German navy, led by U-boats, was trying to intercept this transport. If the Allies had failed at the time, Germany would have probably conquered Britain just as it had conquered other European countries.
ref: Using ships to transport goods is by far the most efficient way to move large amounts of people and goods across oceans. The job of navies has traditionally been to ensure that your country maintains the ability to move your people and goods, while at the same time, interfering with your enemy's ability to move his people and goods. One of the most noteworthy recent examples of this was the North Atlantic campaign of WWII. The Americans were trying to move men and materials across the Atlantic Ocean to help Britain. At the same time, the German navy, using mainly U-boats, was trying to stop this traffic. Had the Allies failed, Germany probably would have been able to conquer Britain as it had the rest of Europe.

src: 辐轮的发明使亚述人的战车更轻便、更迅速，行驶起来可以更轻松地超过士兵和其他战车。 他们从致命的十字弓中射出的利箭，能穿透敌军的盔甲。公元前 1000 年前后，亚述人使用了第一批骑兵。 骑兵是指在马背上作战的军队。当时尚未发明马鞍，因此亚述骑兵只能骑在光秃秃的马背上作战。
mt: The invention of the wheel made Assyrian chariots lighter and faster, and easier to maneuver over soldiers and other chariots. Their arrows, shot from crossbows, could pierce enemy armor. Around 1000 B.C., Assyrians used the first cavalry. Cavalry refers to troops that fight from horseback. At the time, saddles had not yet been invented, so Assyrian cavalry had to fight from bareback horses.
ref: The invention of spoke wheels made Assyrian chariots lighter, faster, and better prepared to outrun soldiers and other chariots. Arrows from their deadly crossbows could penetrate the armor of rival soldiers. About 1000 B.C., the Assyrians introduced the first cavalry. A cavalry is an army that fights on horseback. The saddle had not yet been invented, so the Assyrian cavalry fought on the bare backs of their horses.

src: 巴比伦人为他们每位神祇都建造了一座主殿，将其视为该神居所。 人们会把祭品献给神，牧师会通过仪式和节庆来满足神的需要。 每所神殿都有一处对外开放的庭院，以及一处只有祭司才能进入的内殿。 有些特殊的塔呈金字塔形状，被称为金字形神塔，是作为庙宇的一部分而建造的。 塔顶是上帝的特殊圣地。
mt: The Babylonians built a main temple for each of their gods, which they considered to be the god's home. People would offer sacrifices to the gods, and priests would satisfy the gods' needs through rituals and celebrations. Each temple had an open courtyard accessible to the public, and an inner sanctuary accessible only to the priests. Some special towers were shaped like pyramids and were called ziggurats, which were built as part of the temple. The top of the tower was a special holy place for the gods.
ref: The Babylonians built each of their gods a primary temple that was considered the home of the god. People would bring sacrifices to the gods and the priests would try to attend to the needs of the gods through ceremonies and festivals. Each temple had an open temple courtyard and then an inner sanctuary that only the priests could enter. Sometimes special pyramid shaped towers, called ziggurats, were built to be a part of the temples. The top of the tower was special sanctuary for the god.

src: 是的！图坦卡蒙国王，有时也被称为“图特王”或“少年国王”，他是现代最著名的古埃及国王之一。 有趣的是，他在古代并不被认为是举足轻重的人物，而且不被记录于大多数古代国王的名单。 然而，1922 年发现了他的墓穴，让他成了名人。虽然有许多过去的坟墓被盗，但这座坟墓几乎未遭破坏。 图坦卡蒙的大部分陪葬品都保存完好，其中包括数千件由贵金属和稀有宝石制成的文物。
mt: Yes! Tutankhamun, sometimes called Tutankhamun or the Young King, is one of the most famous ancient Egyptian kings of modern times. Interestingly, he was not considered a major figure in ancient times and was not recorded in most lists of ancient kings. However, his tomb was discovered in 1922, making him a celebrity. Although many past tombs have been looted, this tomb was almost undamaged. Most of Tutankhamun's burial goods were preserved, including thousands of items made of precious metals and rare gemstones.
ref: "Yes! King Tutankhamun, sometimes referred to as ""King Tut"" or ""The Boy King"", is one of the most well known ancient Egyptian kings in modern times. Interestingly, he was not considered to be very important in ancient times and was not recorded on most ancient king lists. However, the discovery of his tomb in 1922 made him a celebrity. While many tombs of the past were robbed, this tomb was left virtually undisturbed. Most of the items buried with Tutankhamun have been well preserved, including thousands of artefacts made from precious metals and rare stones."

src: 我们知道许多希腊政治家、科学家和艺术家。希腊文化中最有名的人可能是有着传奇色彩的盲人诗人荷马。他创作了希腊文学的两部杰作：《伊利亚特》和《奥德赛》。 索福克勒斯（Sophocles ）和阿里斯托芬（Aristophanes）仍然是受欢迎的剧作家，他们的戏剧被认为是世界文学中最伟大的作品之一。 另一个著名的希腊人是数学家毕达哥拉斯，他最有名的成就是提出了关于直角三角形各边关系的著名定理。
mt: We know many Greek politicians, scientists and artists. The most famous person in Greek culture may be the blind poet Homer, who wrote two masterpieces of Greek literature, the Iliad and the Odyssey. Sophocles and Aristophanes are still popular playwrights, whose plays are considered one of the greatest works in world literature. Another famous Greek is the mathematician Pythagoras, who is best known for his famous theorem on the relationship of the sides of a right triangle.
ref: We know many Greek politicians, scientists, and artists. Possibly the most known person of this culture is Homer, the legendary blind poet, who composed two masterpieces of Greek literature: the poems Iliad and Odyssey. Sophocles and Aristophanes are still popular playwrights and their plays are considered to be among the greatest works of world literature. Another famous Greek is a mathematician Pythagoras, mostly known for his famous theorem about relations of the sides of right triangles.

Sophocles and Aristophanes are still popular playwrights and their plays are considered to be among the greatest works of world literature. Another famous Greek is a mathematician Pythagoras, mostly known for his famous theorem about relations of the sides of right triangles.

src: 在中东温暖的气候中，房子并不是多重要。 希伯来家庭的生活大多是在户外度过的。 女人们在院子里做饭；商店其实就是面向街道的开放柜台。他们用石头来建造房屋。 迦南没有大森林，所以木材非常昂贵。
mt: In the warm climate of the Middle East, houses are not very important. The lives of Hebrew families are mostly spent outdoors. Women cook in the yard; shops are actually open counters facing the street. They use stones to build houses. Canaan has no large forests, so wood is very expensive.
ref: In the warm climate of the Middle East, the house was not so important. Most of the life of the Hebrew family happened in the open air. Women did the cooking in the yard; stores were just open counters looking into the street. Stone was used for building houses. There were no large forests in the land of Canaan, so wood was extremely expensive.

src: 格陵兰岛人烟稀少。据北欧史诗萨迦记载，红胡子埃里克因犯谋杀罪被逐出冰岛，他向西航行，发现陆地，于是将其命名为格陵兰岛。 但不管他有没有发现，爱斯基摩人当时已经在那里生活了。 虽然均隶属于“斯堪的纳维亚”，但丹麦、瑞典、挪威和冰岛的民众、国王、习俗和历史之间存在着许多差异。
mt: Greenland is sparsely populated. According to the Norse sagas, Erik the Red was banished from Iceland for manslaughter. He went westward and discovered land, which he named Greenland. But whether he did or not, the Inuit had already been living there. Although all are part of "Scandinavia", there are many differences between the people, kings, customs and history of the Danes, Swedes, Norwegians and Icelanders.
ref: Greenland was settled sparsely. In the Norse sagas they say that Erik the Red was exiled from Iceland for murder, and when travelling further west, found Greenland and named it Greenland. But regardless of his discovery, Eskimo tribes were already living there at the time. Though each country was 'Scandinavian', there were many differences between the people, kings, customs and history of Denmark, Sweden, Norway and Iceland.

src: 尽管罗马人的大部分食物是我们所常见的，但他们确实有一些奇怪或不寻常的宴会菜肴，包括野猪、孔雀、蜗牛和一种叫做榛睡鼠的啮齿动物 另一个不同之处在于，穷人和女人坐在椅子上吃饭，富人则喜欢聚在一起举行宴会，侧卧着吃饭。 几个世纪后从美洲或亚洲传入欧洲的食物不可能出现在古罗马人的饮食当中。 例如，他们没有玉米、西红柿、土豆和可可，也没有哪个古罗马人吃过火鸡。
mt: Although most of the Romans' food was familiar to us, they did have some strange or unusual banquet dishes, including wild boar, peacocks, snails and a rodent called dormice. Another difference was that the poor and women sat on chairs to eat, while the rich preferred to gather together for a banquet and eat lying down. Foods that could not have been on the ancient Romans' menu include maize, tomatoes, potatoes and cocoa, and no Roman ever ate turkey.
ref: While most of their food would be familiar to us, Romans did have their share of strange or unusual feast items, including wild boar, peacock, snails, and a type of rodent called a dormouse Another difference was that while the poor people and the woman ate their food while sitting in chairs, the rich men liked to have banquets together where they would lounge on their sides while they ate their meals. Ancient Roman meals couldn't have included foods that came to Europe from America or from Asia in later centuries. For instance, they didn't have corn, nor tomatoes, nor potatoes, nor cocoa, and no ancient Roman ever tasted a turkey.

src: "文明是一种由共同生活、合作工作的人群（社会）所共享的单一文化。 “文明”一词来自拉丁语“civilis”（意为“公民的”），与拉丁语""civis""（意为“公民”）及""civitas""（意为“城市”或“城邦”）都有关，这也以某种方式定义了社会的规模。 城邦是民族的前身。文明型文化意味着知识的代代相传，文化的足迹萦绕留存，还有文化能够公平地传播。 少数民族文化常常没有留下相关的历史证据就消失无踪，而且不被当做是像样的文明。"
mt: "Civilization is a shared culture of a society of people living together and working together. The word "civilization" comes from the Latin "civilis" (meaning "of a citizen"), which is related to the Latin "civis" (meaning "citizen") and "civitas" (meaning "city" or "city-state"), which in some way defines the scale of a society. The city-state is the predecessor of the nation. A civilized culture means the transmission of knowledge from generation to generation, the traces of culture are left behind, and the culture can be fairly spread. The culture of minority ethnic groups often disappears without a trace and is not considered a civilized culture."
ref: A civilization is a singular culture shared by a significant large group of people who live and work co-operatively, a society. The word civilization comes from the Latin civilis, meaning civil, related to the Latin civis, meaning citizen, and civitas, meaning city or city-state, and that also somehow defines the size of the society. City-states are the precursors of nations. A civilizational culture implies the passing on of knowledge across several generations, a lingering cultural footprint and fair dissemination. Minor cultures often vanish without leaving relevant historic evidence and fail to be recognized as proper civilizations.

src: 朱克杰宗（Drukgyal Dzong）是一座已毁的堡垒和佛教寺庙，位于帕罗区上部（在方德村）。 据说扎布隆·阿旺·纳姆耶尔 (Zhabdrung nawang Namgyel) 于 1649 年建造这座堡垒，是为了纪念自己战胜藏蒙军队。 1951 年，一场大火导致杜克耶堡仅存一丝遗迹，例如扎布隆·阿旺·纳姆格亚尔（Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyal）的雕像。 火灾过后，堡垒得到维护和保护，成为不丹最备受瞩目的景点之一。
mt: Drukgyal Dzong is a ruined fortress and Buddhist temple located in the upper Paro valley (above Drukgyal Village). It is said that Zhabdrung Nawang Namgyel built this fortress in 1649 to commemorate his victory over the Tibetan-Mongolian forces. In 1951, a fire destroyed Drukgyal Dzong leaving only a few remnants, such as the statue of Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyal. After the fire, the fortress was maintained and protected, becoming one of Bhutan's most popular tourist destinations.
ref: The Drukgyal Dzong is a ruined fortress and Buddhist monastery in the upper part of the Paro District (in Phondey Village). It is said that in 1649, Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyel created the fortress to commemorate his victory against the Tibetan-Mongol forces. In 1951, a fire caused for only some of the relics of the Drukgyal Dzong to remain, such as the image of Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyal. After the fire, the fortress was preserved and protected, remaining to be one of Bhutan's most sensational attractions.

src: 18 世纪的柬埔寨被夹在泰国和越南两个强邻之间。 泰国人在 18 世纪曾多次入侵柬埔寨，并在 1772 年摧毁了金边。 在 18 世纪的最后几年，越南人也入侵了柬埔寨。
mt: 18th century Cambodia was sandwiched between two powerful neighbors, Thailand and Vietnam. Thailand invaded Cambodia several times in the 18th century, and destroyed Phnom Penh in 1772. In the last few years of the 18th century, Vietnam also invaded Cambodia.
ref: During the 18th century Cambodia found itself squeezed between two powerful neighbors, Thailand and Vietnam. The Thais invaded Cambodia several times in the 18th century and in 1772 they destroyed Phnom Phen. In the last years of the 18th century the Vietnamese also invaded Cambodia.

src: 18 世纪的柬埔寨被夹在泰国和越南两个强邻之间。 泰国人在 18 世纪曾多次入侵柬埔寨，并在 1772 年摧毁了金边。 在 18 世纪的最后几年，越南人也入侵了柬埔寨。
mt: 18th century Cambodia was sandwiched between two powerful neighbors, Thailand and Vietnam. Thailand invaded Cambodia several times in the 18th century, and destroyed Phnom Penh in 1772. In the last few years of the 18th century, Vietnam also invaded Cambodia.
ref: During the 18th century Cambodia found itself squeezed between two powerful neighbors, Thailand and Vietnam. The Thais invaded Cambodia several times in the 18th century and in 1772 they destroyed Phnom Phen. In the last years of the 18th century the Vietnamese also invaded Cambodia.

src: 西方对台湾的了解可以追溯到 15 世纪。当时路过的欧洲水手将该岛命名为“福尔摩沙岛”(Ilha Formosa)，意思是美丽的岛屿。 1624 年，荷兰东印度公司在台湾地区西南部建立基地，开始改变原住民的粮食生产方式，并雇佣华工在其水稻和蔗糖种植园工作。 1683 年，清朝（1644年 - 1912年）军队控制了台湾西部和北部沿海地区，1885 年，大清帝国宣布在台湾建省。 1895 年，在甲午战争 (1894-1895 年) 中战败后，清政府签署了《马关条约》，将台湾的主权割让给日本，日本统治台湾直至 1945 年。
mt: 15th century, European sailors passing by named the island "Ilha Formosa", meaning "beautiful island". In 1624, the Dutch East India Company established a base in southwestern Taiwan and began changing the indigenous people's food production methods by hiring Chinese workers in its rice and sugar plantations. In 1683, Qing army controlled the western and northern coastal areas of Taiwan, and in 1885, the Qing government announced the establishment of Taiwan Province. In 1895, after losing the Sino-Japanese War (1894-1895), the Qing government signed the Treaty of Shimonoseki, ceding Taiwan's sovereignty to Japan, which ruled Taiwan until 1945.
ref: Taiwan beginning start way back in 15th century where European sailors passing by record the island’s name as Ilha Formosa, or beautiful island. In 1624,Dutch East India Company establishes a base in southwestern Taiwan, initiating a transformation in aboriginal grain production practices and employing Chinese laborers to work on its rice and sugar plantations. In 1683, Qing dynasty (1644-1912) forces take control of Taiwan’s western and northern coastal areas and declared Taiwan as a province of the Qing Empire in 1885. In 1895, after defeat in the First Sino-Japanese War (1894-1895), the Qing government signs the Treaty of Shimonoseki, by which it cedes sovereignty over Taiwan to Japan, which rules the island until 1945.

src: 这被称为化学物质的 pH 值。你可以使用红甘蓝汁制作指示剂。 卷心菜汁的颜色将根据化学物质的酸碱性发生变化。 pH 值以被测化学品中的氢（pH 中的 H）离子数量表示。 氢离子是失去了电子的质子（因为氢原子由一个质子和一个电子组成）。
mt: This is called the pH of the chemical. You can make an indicator with red cabbage juice. The color of the beet juice will change according to the acidity of the chemical. The pH value is the number of hydrogen (H) ions in the tested chemical. Hydrogen ions are protons that have lost an electron (because hydrogen atoms are made up of one proton and one electron).
ref: This is called a chemical's pH. You can make an indicator using red cabbage juice. The cabbage juice changes color depending on how acidic or basic (alkaline) the chemical is. The pH level is indicated by the amount of Hydrogen (the H in pH) ions in the tested chemical. Hydrogen ions are protons that had their electrons stripped off them (since Hydrogen atoms consist of one proton and one electron).

src: 狮子是群居属性最明显的猫科动物，生活在称为狮群的大型群体中。 狮群由一到三只有亲属关系的成年雄性，以及可多达三十只的雌性和幼崽组成。 作为大家庭里的姐妹和女儿，雌性之间通常彼此关系密切。 狮群的行为与狼群或狗群非常类似。这些动物与狮子的行为惊人地相似（但与其他大型猫科动物不同），而且这些行为对它们的猎物来说也是非常致命的。
mt: Lions are the most social of the cat species, living in large groups called prides. A pride consists of one to three related adult males, and as many as 30 females and their young. As sisters and daughters in the family, females are usually closely related. The behavior of lions is very similar to that of wolves and dogs, and these animals are remarkably similar to lions (but different from other large cats), and these behaviors are very deadly to their prey.
ref: Lions are the most social cats, living in large groups called prides. Prides are made up of one to three related adult males, along with as many as thirty females and cubs. The females are usually closely related to each other, being a large family of sisters and daughters. Lion prides act much like packs of wolves or dogs, animals surprisingly similar to lions (but not other big cats) in behavior, and also very deadly to their prey.

src: 它们的下方是更多中等大小的猫科动物，它们吃的是中等大小的猎物，从兔子、羚羊到鹿都会吃。 最终，有许多小型的猫科动物（包括散养的宠物猫），以昆虫、啮齿动物、蜥蜴和鸟类等数量多得多的小型猎物为食。 它们成功的秘诀是利基概念，每只猫都负责一项特殊的工作，防止它们与其他猫竞争。
mt: Below them are more medium-sized cats that eat medium-sized prey, from rabbits, antelopes to deer. Eventually, there are many small cats (including domesticated pets), eating insects, rodents, lizards and birds, etc. The secret of their success is the niche concept, each cat is responsible for a special work, preventing them from competing with other cats.
ref: Under them are more medium sized cats that eat medium sized prey ranging from rabbits to antelopes and deer. Finally, there are many small cats (including loose pet cats) that eat the far more numerous small prey like insects, rodents, lizards, and birds. The secret to their success is the concept of the niche, a special job each cat holds that keeps it from competing with others.

src: 它们的下方是更多中等大小的猫科动物，它们吃的是中等大小的猎物，从兔子、羚羊到鹿都会吃。 最终，有许多小型的猫科动物（包括散养的宠物猫），以昆虫、啮齿动物、蜥蜴和鸟类等数量多得多的小型猎物为食。 它们成功的秘诀是利基概念，每只猫都负责一项特殊的工作，防止它们与其他猫竞争。
mt: Below them are more medium-sized cats that eat medium-sized prey, from rabbits, antelopes to deer. Eventually, there are many small cats (including domesticated pets), eating insects, rodents, lizards and birds, etc. The secret of their success is the niche concept, each cat is responsible for a special work, preventing them from competing with other cats.
ref: Under them are more medium sized cats that eat medium sized prey ranging from rabbits to antelopes and deer. Finally, there are many small cats (including loose pet cats) that eat the far more numerous small prey like insects, rodents, lizards, and birds. The secret to their success is the concept of the niche, a special job each cat holds that keeps it from competing with others.

src: 豹猫喜欢吃小动物。如果条件允许，他们会捕捉猴子、蛇、啮齿动物和鸟类。豹猫的猎物几乎都比自身要小得多。 科学家认为，美洲豹猫是通过气味和嗅探猎物在地面上的踪迹来跟踪和寻找要捕食的动物的。 它们的夜视能力很强，能在黑暗中看得很清楚，而且行动也很隐秘。豹猫的捕食方式是先融入周围环境，然后猛扑向猎物。
mt: Jaguars like to eat small animals. If conditions allow, they will catch monkeys, snakes, rodents and birds. The jaguars' prey are almost always smaller than themselves. Scientists believe that jaguars track and find prey to eat by scent and by following tracks on the ground. They have good night vision and can see clearly in the dark, and they are also very stealthy. Jaguars hunt by blending into their surroundings and then pouncing on their prey.
ref: Ocelots like to eat small animals. They will catch monkeys, snakes, rodents and birds if they can. Almost all of the animals that the ocelot hunts are far smaller than it is. Scientists think that ocelots follow and find animals to eat (prey) by smell, sniffing for where they've been on the ground. They can see very well in the dark with night vision, and move very stealthily, too. Ocelots hunt their prey by blending in with their surroundings then pouncing on their prey.

src: 老虎是全能运动员，它会攀爬（虽然攀爬能力不是很强）、游泳、跳远，拉力能达到人类大力士的五倍。 老虎与狮、豹和美洲虎属于同一类型（豹属）。这四种大猫是仅有的会吼叫的猫科动物。 老虎的咆哮不像狮子的咆哮那样深沉，而更像一句生气嘶吼的话语。
mt: Tigers are all-round athletes, able to climb, swim, and jump, and pull with a force five times that of a human strongman. Tigers, lions, leopards, and jaguars are all members of the same type (leopards). These four big cats are the only cats that roar. A tiger's roar is not as deep as a lion's roar, but more like an angry growl.
ref: A well rounded athlete, the tiger can climb (though not well), swim, leap great distances and pull with five times the force of a strong human. The tiger is in the same group (Genus Panthera) as lions, leopards, and jaguars. These four cats are the only ones who can roar. The tiger's roar is not like the full-voiced roar of a lion, but more like a sentence of snarly, shouted words.

src: 细胞是各类生物体中最小的结构和功能单位。 Cell（细胞）一词源自拉丁语cella（意思是小房间）。 在显微镜下观察生物，你会发现它们是由小方块或小球组成的。 来自英国的生物学家罗伯特·胡克 (Robert Hooke) 用显微镜看到了软木塞中藏有一些小方块。 它们看上去像房间。他是第一个观察死亡细胞的人
mt: Cells are the smallest structural and functional units of a biological organism. The word cell comes from the Latin cellula, meaning "small room".  Under a microscope, an organism is seen to be made up of many cells. In 1665, Robert Hooke observed cells when he looked at a piece of cork through a microscope. He saw that the cork was made up of many small boxes. He called them cells.
ref: A cell is the smallest structural and functional unit of a living (things) organism. Cell comes from the Latin word cella which means small room. If you look at living things under a microscope, you will see that they are made of small squares or balls. Robert Hooke, a biologist from England, saw small squares in cork with a microscope. They looked like rooms. He was the first person to observe dead cells

src: 动物由许多细胞组成。动物吃了食物后会在体内将其消化。大部分动物都能移动。 只有动物有脑（但也不是所有动物都有，比如水母就没有脑）。 地球上的各个角落都有动物的身影。它们有的在地下挖洞，有的在海洋中畅游，有的在天空中翱翔。
mt: Animals are made up of many cells. Animals digest food inside their bodies after eating. Most animals can move. Only animals have brains (but not all animals do, like jellyfish don't have brains). Animals can be found in every corner of the Earth. Some live underground, some swim in the ocean, and some fly in the sky.
ref: Animals are made of many cells. They eat things and digest them inside. Most animals can move. Only animals have brains (though not even all animals do; jellyfish, for example, do not have brains). Animals are found all over the earth. They dig in the ground, swim in the oceans, and fly in the sky.

src: 植物能制造人类吸入的氧气，吸收人类呼出的二氧化碳。 植物通过光合作用从阳光中获取养分。它们还能提供荫凉。 我们用植物做房子，用植物做衣服。我们吃的大部分食物都是植物。没有植物，动物就不能生存。
mt: Plants make the oxygen we breathe and absorb the carbon dioxide we exhale. Plants get their nutrients from sunlight through photosynthesis. They also provide shade. We build houses with plants, we make clothes with plants. Most of the food we eat is plant-based. Without plants, animals cannot survive.
ref: Plants make oxygen which humans breathe, and they take in carbon-dioxide which humans exhale (that is, breathe out). Plants make their food from the sun by photosynthesis. They also provide shade. We make our houses from plants and make clothes from plants. Most foods that we eat are plants. Without plants, animals could not survive.

We build houses with plants, we make clothes with plants. Most of the food we eat is plant-based. Without plants, animals cannot survive.

They also provide shade. We make our houses from plants and make clothes from plants. Most foods that we eat are plants. Without plants, animals could not survive.

src: 当一小群生物（一个小种群）与它们本来的主要种群分离时（比如它们跨过山脉和河流，或者它们到了一个新的岛屿以至于不可能轻易回去)，它们通常会发现自己所处的环境与之前不同。 这个新的环境有不同的资源和不同的竞争对手，所以新的种群将需要不同的特征或适应能力来成为一个强有力的竞争对手，而不是它们之前所需要的那些。 原来的种群根本没有改变，它们仍需要和以前一样适应环境。 随着时间的推移，新的种群开始适应新的环境，它们开始变得与其他种群越来越不相似了。 在历经数千甚至数百万年以后，这两个种群最终看上去会截然不同，以致于不能将两者称作同一物种。 我们把这个过程称为“物种形成”，也就是新物种的形成。物种形成是进化的必然结果，也是进化中极为重要的一环。
mt: When a small group of organisms (a small population) becomes separated from its main population (for example, by crossing a mountain range or a river, or by getting to a new island that they can't easily get back from), they will often find themselves in an environment that is different from the one they were used to. This new environment has different resources and different competitors, so the new population will need different traits or adaptive abilities to be a strong competitor, rather than the ones they needed before. The original population hasn't changed, they still need to adapt to the environment as they did before. As time goes on, the new population starts to adapt to the new environment, and they start to look less and less like the other populations. After thousands or even millions of years, the two populations will look so different that they can't be called the same species. We call this process "speciation", or the formation of a new species. Speciation is an inevitable result of evolution, and is also one of the most important parts of evolution.
ref: When a small group of living things (a small population) gets separated from the main population that they came from (like if they move over a mountain range or a river, or if they move to a new island so that they can't easily move back) they will often find themselves in a different environment than they were in before. This new environment has different resources and different competitors, so the new population will need different features or adaptations to be a strong competitor than what they had needed before. The original population hasn't changed at all, they still need the same adaptations as before. Over time, as the new population begins to adapt to their new environment, they start to look less and less like the other population. Eventually, after thousands or even millions of years, the two populations will look so different that they can't be called the same species. We call this process speciation, which just means the formation of new species. Speciation is an unavoidable consequence and a very important part of evolution.

src: 循环系统的主要器官是心脏，心脏负责输送血液。 血液通过被称为动脉的管道从心脏流出，然后通过称为静脉的管道回流到心脏。最小的管道叫做毛细血管。
mt: The main organs of the circulatory system are the heart, which pumps blood, and the blood vessels, through which the blood flows. The smallest blood vessels are called capillaries.
ref: The major organ of the circulatory system is the heart, which pumps the blood. Blood goes away from the heart in tubes called arteries and comes back to the heart in tubes called veins. The smallest tubes are called capillaries.

src: 循环系统的主要器官是心脏，心脏负责输送血液。 血液通过被称为动脉的管道从心脏流出，然后通过称为静脉的管道回流到心脏。最小的管道叫做毛细血管。

ref: The major organ of the circulatory system is the heart, which pumps the blood. Blood goes away from the heart in tubes called arteries and comes back to the heart in tubes called veins. The smallest tubes are called capillaries.

src: 昆虫是最早在空中飞行的动物。飞行能力让它们更容易躲避敌人，更有效地寻找食物和配偶。 大多数昆虫都具有一种优势，可以将翅膀沿身体向后折叠。 这让它们有了更多小面积空间来躲避捕食者。 如今，唯一不能向后折叠翅膀的昆虫是蜻蜓和蜉蝣。
mt: Insects are the earliest animals to fly. The ability to fly makes them easier to evade predators, and more effective at finding food and mates. Most insects have an advantage in that they can fold their wings along their body. This gives them more small surface area to hide from predators. Today, the only insects that cannot fold their wings backwards are dragonflies and mayflies.
ref: Insects were the first animals to take to the air. Their ability to fly helped them evade enemies more easily and find food and mates more efficiently. Most insects have the advantage of being able to fold their wings back along the body. This gives them a wider range of small places to hide from predators. Today, the only insects that cannot fold back their wings are dragon flies and mayflies.

src: 昆虫是最早在空中飞行的动物。飞行能力让它们更容易躲避敌人，更有效地寻找食物和配偶。 大多数昆虫都具有一种优势，可以将翅膀沿身体向后折叠。 这让它们有了更多小面积空间来躲避捕食者。 如今，唯一不能向后折叠翅膀的昆虫是蜻蜓和蜉蝣。

src: 许多古生物学家相信有一群恐龙存活了下来，并一直存活至今，也就是我们所称的“鸟类”。 很多人认为它们并非恐龙，因为它们有羽毛，会飞。 但鸟类还是有很多地方跟恐龙相似。 它们脚上有鳞片和爪子，会产卵，还像霸王龙一样用两条后腿走路。
mt: Many paleontologists believe that a group of dinosaurs survived and have been around ever since, which is what we call "birds." Many people think they are not dinosaurs because they have feathers and can fly. But birds still have many things in common with dinosaurs. They have scales and claws on their feet, lay eggs, and like the tyrannosaurus, they walk on two legs.
ref: Many paleontologists today believe that one group of dinosaurs survived and is alive today. We call them birds. Many people don't think about them as dinosaurs because they have feathers and can fly. But there are a lot of things about birds that still look like a dinosaur. They have feet with scales and claws, they lay eggs, and they walk on their two back legs like a T-Rex.

src: 许多古生物学家相信有一群恐龙存活了下来，并一直存活至今，也就是我们所称的“鸟类”。 很多人认为它们并非恐龙，因为它们有羽毛，会飞。 但鸟类还是有很多地方跟恐龙相似。 它们脚上有鳞片和爪子，会产卵，还像霸王龙一样用两条后腿走路。

ref: Many paleontologists today believe that one group of dinosaurs survived and is alive today. We call them birds. Many people don't think about them as dinosaurs because they have feathers and can fly. But there are a lot of things about birds that still look like a dinosaur. They have feet with scales and claws, they lay eggs, and they walk on their two back legs like a T-Rex.

src: 三角龙的牙齿不仅能咬碎树叶，还能咬碎非常坚硬的树枝和树根。 一些科学家认为，三角龙以苏铁为食，苏铁是白垩纪时期很常见的一种植物。 这些植物看起来像一棵小棕榈树，树冠由钉子般的锋利叶子组成。 在吃树干之前，三角龙会用它强有力的喙嘴剥去树叶。 其他科学家认为这些植物有毒，所以恐龙不太可能吃它们，即便现在树懒和其他动物例如鹦鹉（恐龙的后代）可以吃有毒的叶子或水果。
mt: 3-horned dinosaurs had teeth that could bite through leaves, but also through very hard branches and roots. Some scientists think that the 3-horned dinosaurs ate cycads, a very common plant in the Cretaceous period. These plants look like a small palm tree, with a crown of sharp-pointed leaves. Before eating the trunk, the 3-horned dinosaurs would use their strong beaks to strip off the leaves. Other scientists think these plants were poisonous, so the dinosaurs probably didn't eat them, even though now sloths and other animals such as parrots (the descendants of dinosaurs) can eat poisonous leaves or fruit.
ref: A triceratops' teeth would have been able to crush not only leaves but even very tough branches and roots. Some scientists think Triceratops ate cycads, which are a type of plant that was common in the Cretaceous. These plants look like a small palm tree with a crown of sharp, spiky leaves. A Triceratops could have used its strong beak to strip off the leaves before eating the trunk. Other scientists argue that these plants are very poisonous so it is unlikely that any dinosaur ate them, even though today the sloth and other animals like the parrot (a descendant of the dinosaurs) can eat poisonous leaves or fruit.

src: 三角龙的牙齿不仅能咬碎树叶，还能咬碎非常坚硬的树枝和树根。 一些科学家认为，三角龙以苏铁为食，苏铁是白垩纪时期很常见的一种植物。 这些植物看起来像一棵小棕榈树，树冠由钉子般的锋利叶子组成。 在吃树干之前，三角龙会用它强有力的喙嘴剥去树叶。 其他科学家认为这些植物有毒，所以恐龙不太可能吃它们，即便现在树懒和其他动物例如鹦鹉（恐龙的后代）可以吃有毒的叶子或水果。
mt: 3-horned dinosaurs had teeth that could bite through leaves, but also through very hard branches and roots. Some scientists think that the 3-horned dinosaurs ate cycads, a very common plant in the Cretaceous period. These plants look like a small palm tree, with a crown of sharp-pointed leaves. Before eating the trunk, the 3-horned dinosaurs would use their strong beaks to strip off the leaves. Other scientists think these plants were poisonous, so the dinosaurs probably didn't eat them, even though now sloths and other animals such as parrots (the descendants of dinosaurs) can eat poisonous leaves or fruit.
ref: A triceratops' teeth would have been able to crush not only leaves but even very tough branches and roots. Some scientists think Triceratops ate cycads, which are a type of plant that was common in the Cretaceous. These plants look like a small palm tree with a crown of sharp, spiky leaves. A Triceratops could have used its strong beak to strip off the leaves before eating the trunk. Other scientists argue that these plants are very poisonous so it is unlikely that any dinosaur ate them, even though today the sloth and other animals like the parrot (a descendant of the dinosaurs) can eat poisonous leaves or fruit.

src: 意大利国家足球队和德国国家足球队都是世界上第二成功的球队，在 2006 年拿下了足球世界杯冠军。 流行的运动项目包括足球、篮球、排球、水球、击剑、橄榄球、自行车、冰球、轮滑曲棍球和一级方程式赛车。 冬季运动在北部地区最受欢迎，意大利人会在那里参加国际比赛和奥运会比赛。
mt: Italy and Germany are the second most successful national teams in the world, winning the World Cup in 2006. Popular sports include football, basketball, volleyball, water polo, fencing, rugby, cycling, ice hockey, roller hockey, and Formula One racing. Winter sports are most popular in the north, where Italians compete in international competitions and the Olympics.
ref: Italy's national football, along with German national football team is the second most successful team in the world and were the FIFA World Cup champions in 2006. Popular sports include football, basketball, volleyball, water-polo, fencing, rugby, cycling, ice hockey, roller hockey and F1 motor racing. Winter sports are most popular in the Northern regions, with Italians competing in international games and Olympic events.

src: 卢森堡历史悠久，但在 1839 年才独立成国。 今天的比利时有部分地区过去属于卢森堡，但在 19 世纪 30 年代的比利时革命后被划入比利时。 卢森堡一直试图成为中立国，但它在第一次世界大战和第二次世界大战中都曾被德国占领。 1957 年，卢森堡成为如今被称为欧盟的组织的创始成员国。
mt: Luxembourg has a long history, but only became independent in 1839.  Parts of today's Belgium were once part of Luxembourg, but were incorporated into Belgium after the Belgian Revolution of the 1830s.  Luxembourg has always tried to be a neutral country, but was occupied by Germany in both World War I and World War II.  Luxembourg was a founding member of the organization now known as the EU in 1957.
ref: Luxembourg has a long history but its independence dates from 1839. Present-day parts of Belgium were part of Luxembourg in the past but became Belgian after the 1830s Belgian Revolution. Luxembourg has always tried to remain a neutral country but it was occupied in both World War I and World War II by Germany. In 1957 Luxembourg became a founding member of the organization which is today known as the European Union.

src: 土耳其位于欧洲的部分（地处巴尔干半岛的东色雷斯或鲁米利亚）占其国土面积的 3％。 土耳其领土长 1,600 多公里（1,000 英里），宽 800 公里（500 英里），大致呈矩形。 土耳其的国土面积（包括湖泊）为 783,562 平方公里（300,948 平方英里），其中 755,688 平方公里（291,773 平方英里）位于西南亚，23,764 平方公里（9,174 平方英里）位于欧洲。 土耳其的面积在世界上排第 37 位，大约是法国本土和英国面积的总和。 土耳其三面环海：西面是爱琴海，北面是黑海，南面则是地中海。
mt: 3% of Turkey is in Europe (in the eastern part of the Balkan Peninsula, or Rumelia). Turkey is about 1,600 km (1,000 mi) long and 800 km (500 mi) wide, and is roughly rectangular in shape. Turkey's land area (including lakes) is 783,562 km² (300,948 sq mi), of which 755,688 km² (291,773 sq mi) is in Southwest Asia and 23,764 km² (9,174 sq mi) is in Europe. Turkey's area ranks 37th in the world, about the combined area of France and the United Kingdom. Turkey is surrounded by sea on three sides: the Aegean Sea to the west, the Black Sea to the north, and the Mediterranean Sea to the south.
ref: European Turkey (eastern Thrace or Rumelia in the Balkan peninsula) includes 3% of the country. The territory of Turkey is more than 1,600 kilometres (1,000 mi) long and 800 km (500 mi) wide, with a roughly rectangular shape. Turkey's area, including lakes, occupies 783,562 square kilometres (300,948 sq mi), of which 755,688 square kilometres (291,773 sq mi) are in south west Asia and 23,764 square kilometres (9,174 sq mi) in Europe. Turkey's area makes it the world's 37th-largest country, and is about the size of Metropolitan France and the United Kingdom combined. Turkey is encircled by seas on three sides: the Aegean Sea to the west, the Black Sea to the north and the Mediterranean Sea to the south.

src: 梵蒂冈城的人口大约有 800 人。它是世界上最小的独立国家，也是人口最少的国家。 梵蒂冈城在法律法规和官方通信中使用意大利语。 意大利语也是大部分在该国工作的人日常使用的语言，拉丁语则常使用于宗教仪式。 梵蒂冈城的所有公民均为罗马天主教徒。
mt: Vatican City has a population of about 800. It is the smallest independent country in the world and the least populous. Italian is used in legal and official communications in Vatican City. Italian is the language most commonly used by the people working in the country, and Latin is commonly used in religious ceremonies. All citizens of Vatican City are Roman Catholics.
ref: Vatican City's population is around 800. It is the smallest independent country in the world and the country with the lowest population. Vatican City uses Italian in its legislation and official communications. Italian is also the everyday language used by most of those who work in the state while Latin is often used in religious ceremonies. All citizens of Vatican City are Roman Catholic.

src: 今天，我们使用计算机处理图片和视频。 复杂的动画可以在计算机上构建，这种类型的动画正越来越多地应用于电视和电影。 录制音乐时往往用复杂的计算机来处理，并把声音混合在一起。
mt: Today, we use computers to process images and video. Complex animations can be built on computers, and this type of animation is increasingly being used in television and film. When recording music, complex computers are often used to process and mix sounds.
ref: Computers today are used to manipulate pictures and videos. Sophisticated animations can be constructed on computers, and this kind of animation is increasingly being used in television and films. Music is often recorded using sophisticated computers to process and mix sounds together.

src: 哈拉帕 (Harappa) 和摩亨佐-达罗 (Mohenjo-daro) 这两个城市几乎每家每户都有抽水马桶，这些马桶与精密的污水处理系统相连。 在希腊克里特岛和圣托里尼米诺斯城市的房屋中发现了污水系统的遗迹。 古埃及、波斯和中国也有厕所。在罗马文明中，厕所有时是男女混合的公共浴室的一部分。
mt: The cities of Harappa and Mohenjo-daro in the Indus Valley Civilization had almost every house with a flush toilet connected to a sophisticated sewage system. Remains of sewage systems have been found in the houses of the Minoan cities of Crete and Santorini. Ancient Egypt, Persia and China also had toilets. In the Roman civilization, the toilets were part of the public baths, which were mixed male and female.
ref: The cities of Harappa and Mohenjo-daro had a flush toilet in almost every house, attached to a sophisticated sewage system. Remains of sewage systems have been found in the houses of the Minoan cities of Crete and Santorini in Greece. There were also toilets in ancient Egypt, Persia and China. In Roman civilization, toilets were sometimes part of public bath houses where men and women were together in mixed company.

src: 现代溜冰鞋的刀刃是双刃的，刃与刃之间有一个凹洞。双刃对冰有更好的抓力（即使是在倾斜的时候）。 由于刀片的底部略弯曲，当刀片歪向其中一侧时，与冰接触的刀边弯曲了。 这样一来，溜冰者就可以转弯。冰刀向右倾斜，溜冰者就转向右边。冰刀向左倾斜，溜冰者就转向左边。
mt: Modern ice skates have double-bladed blades, with a hollow between the blades. The double-blade has better traction on ice, even when tilted.  Because the blades are slightly curved, when the blades are tilted to one side, the edge of the blade curves against the ice. This allows the skater to turn.  When the blade tilts to the right, the skater turns to the right.  When the blade tilts to the left, the skater turns to the left.
ref: The blade on a modern ice skate has a double edge with a concave hollow between them. The two edges allow for a better grasp of the ice, even when tilted. Because the bottom of the blade is slightly curved, as the blade tilts to one side or the other, the edge which is in contact with the ice also curves. This causes the skater to turn. If the skates tilt to the right, the skater turns right, if the skates tilt to the left, the skater turns left.

src: 它们必须消除从光中得到的多余能量。，才能恢复到之前的能量等级。 它们是通过发射一种被称为“光子”的微小光粒子做到这一点的。 科学家把这一过程称为“受激辐射”，因为原子受到强光的刺激，引起光子的发射，而光也是辐射的一种。 下一张图片显示的是原子发射光子的情况。当然，实际上光子要比图片上的样子小得多。 光子甚至比构成原子的物质还要小！
mt: They must get rid of excess energy they get from light, to return to their previous energy level. They do this by emitting a tiny light particle called a photon. Scientists call this process stimulated emission, because atoms are stimulated by strong light to emit photons, which are also a kind of radiation. The next picture shows an atom emitting a photon. Of course, photons are much smaller than the atoms in the picture. Even photons are smaller than the material that makes up atoms!
ref: "To return to their previous energy level, they must get rid of the extra energy they got from the light. They do this by emitting a tiny particle of light called a ""photon"". Scientists call this process ""stimulated emission of radiation"" because the atoms are stimulated by the bright light, causing the emission of a photon of light, and light is a type of radiation. The next picture shows the atoms emitting photons. Of course, in reality photons are a lot smaller than those in the picture. Photons are even smaller than the stuff that makes up atoms!"

src: 使用几百个小时后，灯丝最终被烧坏，而灯泡也不亮了。 然后需要更换灯泡。更换灯泡时必须小心操作。 首先，务必关闭照明灯具的开关或断开电缆连接。 这是因为，当灯泡还有一部分与插座相连时，当你接触到插座内部或灯泡的金属底座时，电流会流入插座（灯泡金属底座的连接处），让你受到严重的电击。
mt: After several hundred hours of use, the filament eventually burns out and the bulb no longer lights. Then you need to replace the bulb. When replacing the bulb, you must be careful. First, turn off the lighting fixture or disconnect the power cord. This is because when the bulb is still partially connected to the socket, when you touch the socket interior or the metal base of the bulb, the current will flow into the socket (where the bulb's metal base is connected), causing you to receive a serious electric shock.
ref: After hundreds of hours of operation the filament in the bulb eventually burns out and the light bulb no longer works. The light bulb then needs replacing. It is necessary to be careful in replacing the light bulb. First, the switch for the light fixture needs to be turned off or the cable disconnected. This is because electricity flowing into the socket where the metallic part of bulb sits can give you a severe electric shock if you touch the inside of the socket or the metal base of the bulb while it is still partly in the socket.

src: 裂变原子弹的工作原理如下：把一个原子核和许多质子及中子聚在一起需要能量。 有点像推着一辆笨重的小推车上山。再次分裂原子核，然后释放一些能量。 有些原子含有不稳定的原子核，这意味着它们很可能会在很少或没有刺激的情况下发生分裂。
mt: The principle of the fission bomb is as follows: to bring together an atomic nucleus and many protons and neutrons requires energy. It is a bit like pushing a heavy cart up a hill. Then split the atomic nucleus and release some energy. Some atoms have unstable atomic nuclei, which means they are likely to split with little or no stimulation.
ref: The fission bomb works on the principle that it takes energy to put together a nucleus with many protons and neutrons. Sort of like rolling a heavy cart up a hill. Splitting the nucleus up again then releases some of that energy. Some atoms have unstable nuclei which means that they tend to break apart with little or no nudging.

src: 你给远在千里之外的人打电话，就会用到卫星。 太空中的卫星接到电话后，几乎是立刻将其反射回去。 卫星是由火箭发射到太空的。科学家在太空中使用望远镜是因为地球的大气层让某些光线和视野产生扭曲。 要把卫星或望远镜送入太空，需要一枚超过 100 英尺高的巨型火箭。
mt: You use satellites to call someone far away. When a satellite receives a call, it almost immediately reflects it back. Satellites are launched into space by rockets. Scientists use telescopes in space because the Earth's atmosphere distorts some light and vision. To launch a satellite or telescope into space, you need a giant rocket that's over 100 feet tall.
ref: When you call someone who is thousands of miles away, you are using a satellite. The satellite in space gets the call and then reflects it back down, almost instantly. The satellite was sent into space by a rocket. Scientists use telescopes in space because the Earth’s atmosphere distorts some of our light and view. It takes a giant rocket over a 100 feet high to put a satellite or telescope in space.
